metadata.titleEn: A China Dataset of soil hydraulic parameters pedotransfer functions for land surface modeling (1980)
metadata.description:
This data uses soil conversion functions to take sand, silt, clay, organic matter, and bulk density as inputs to estimate soil hydrological parameters, including parameters of the Clapp and Hornberger function and van Genuchten and Mualem function, field water holding capacity, and withering coefficient. Median and coefficient of variation (CV) provide estimates.
The data set is in a raster format with a resolution of 30 arc seconds, and the soil is layered vertically into 7 layers with a maximum thickness of 1.38 meters (ie 0-0.045, 0.045--0.091, 0.091--0.166, 0.166--0.289, 0.289-- 0.493, 0.493--0.829, 0.829--1.383 meters).
The data is stored in NetCDF format. The data file name and its description are as follows:
1. THSCH.nc: Saturated water content of FCH
2. PSI_S.nc: Saturated capillary potential of FCH
3. LAMBDA.nc: Pore size distribution index of FCH
4. K_SCH.nc: Saturate hydraulic conductivity of FCH
5. THR.nc: Residual moisture content of FGM
6. THSGM.nc: Saturated water content of FGM
7. ALPHA.nc: The inverse of the air-entry value of FGM
8. N.nc: The shape parameter of FGM
9. L.nc: The pore-connectivity parameter of FGM
10. K_SVG.nc: Saturated hydraulic conductivity of FGM
11. TH33.nc: Water content at -33 kPa of suction pressure, or field capacity
12. TH1500.nc: Water content at -1500 kPa of suction pressure, or permanent wilting point
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in NetCDF format and can be opened and viewed by ArcGIS, ENVI and other relevant software.

background: To simulate runoff and surface energy and moisture fluxes, land surface models (LSMs) require an appropriate description of soil water content. Most LSMs calculate soil water content by numerically solving the Richards equation. To simulate soil water content, h(u) and K(u) and their associated parameters should be determined prior to solving the above equation. However, soil hydraulic properties are highly heterogeneous in space, and their estimates are dependent on local soil characteristics. There is no unique way to relate soil hydraulic properties and soil characteristics. For this reason, various researchers proposed different empirical relationships of soil hydraulic parameters and soil characteristics, referred to as pedotransfer functions (PTFs). Land surface modelers have employed different PTFs to estimate soil hydraulic parameters. Direct measurement of parameters associated with h(u) and K(u) is difficult and in most cases impractical. It is also impossible to obtain sufficient numbers of direct measurements across a region to adequately reflect the spatial heterogeneity of soils. Thus, most soil databases do not provide soil hydraulic parameters associated with h(u) and K(u). Instead, they are usually obtained by PTFs from soil properties that are easily measured and widely available, such as particle size distribution, bulk density (BD), and soil organic matter (SOM) content. Land surface models for numerical weather prediction, climate modeling, and hydrological modeling usually use lookup tables of mean values of hydraulic parameters based on soil textural classes or continuous PTFs provided by Clapp and Hornberger (1978) and Cosby et al. (1984). The inability and uncertainty of PTFs in the estimation of soil hydraulic parameters can be attributed to factors as follows: 1) the intrinsic inability (i.e., PTF structural error) to accurately describe complex physical relationships (Tomasella et al. 2003), 2) the intrinsic inability or uncertainty caused by limited data used for PTF training, and 3) the uncertainty in PTF inputs to reflect soil spatial heterogeneity at different scales.
research objective: The objective of this study is to develop a dataset of the soil hydraulic parameters associated with two empirical soil functions (i.e., a water retention curve and hydraulic conductivity) using multiple pedotransfer functions (PTFs). This study aims to develop a dataset of soil hydraulic parameters over regions of China for different PTFs. As land modelers, we expect that the dataset of the hydraulic parameters associated with FCH and FGM developed in this study could 1) describe spatial variability of the soil hydraulic characteristics in both vertical and horizontal directions, 2) provide multiple choices for users to use either a single set or an ensemble of hydraulic parameters associated with different PTFs, and 3) provide a benchmark dataset (the median values) from multiple PTFs or as a reference dataset.
challenges: The dataset has several distinct advantages even though the accuracy is unknown for lack of in situ and regional measurements. Direct measurement of parameters associated with h(u) and K(u) is difficult and in most cases impractical. It is also impossible to obtain sufficient numbers of direct measurements across a region to adequately reflect the spatial heterogeneity of soils. The inability and uncertainty of PTFs in the estimation of soil hydraulic parameters can be attributed to factors as follows: 1) the intrinsic inability (i.e., PTF structural error) to accurately describe complex physical relationships (Tomasella et al. 2003), 2) the intrinsic inability or uncertainty caused by limited data used for PTF training, and 3) the uncertainty in PTF inputs to reflect soil spatial heterogeneity at different scales. A number of important limitations in our study remain. First, it is still difficult to quantify the precision of the hydraulic parameter data. Second, the information on the spatial distribution of the China soils needs to be updated.
methods: We selected the most frequently used empirical functions for h(u) and K(u), that is, those given by Clapp and Hornberger (1978), as well as those by van Genuchten (1980) and Mualem (1976). In this paper, we describe the development of a China dataset with multiple PTF-derived soil hydraulic parameters of the FCH and FGM. We estimate the hydraulic parameters associated with h(u) and K(u) at 30 x 30 arc second resolution by employing multiple PTFs. We selected five PTFs for estimating the parameters of FCH, five PTFs for FGM, and 10 PTFs for the field capacity and permanent wilting point.
dataset: The dataset is designed specifically for regional land surface modeling for China. The dataset provides 12 estimated parameters and their associated statistical values. The dataset is available at a 30 x 30 arc second geographical spatial resolution and with seven vertical layers to the depth of 1.38 m. The dataset has several distinct advantages even though the accuracy is unknown for lack of in situ and regional measurements. This dataset utilizes the best available soil characteristics dataset for China. The Chinese soil characteristics dataset was derived by using the 1:1 000 000 Soil Map of China and 8595 representative soil profiles. The soil hydraulic parameter dataset produced in this study is available online (at http://globalchange.bnu.edu.cn) for free download.

Definition.Question: What are pedotransfer functions (PTFs) and how are they used in estimating soil hydraulic parameters?
Definition.Answer: Pedotransfer functions (PTFs) are empirical relationships used to estimate soil hydraulic parameters from easily measured soil properties like particle size distribution, bulk density, and soil organic matter content. They are utilized to infer parameters associated with soil water content and hydraulic conductivity, which are crucial for land surface models that simulate runoff, energy, and moisture fluxes.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with direct measurement of soil hydraulic parameters?
Definition.Answer: Direct measurement of soil hydraulic parameters is challenging because it is often impractical and difficult to obtain sufficient numbers of direct measurements across a region to reflect spatial heterogeneity. Additionally, the inability and uncertainty of PTFs in estimating these parameters stem from the structural error of PTFs, limited data used for PTF training, and the uncertainty in PTF inputs reflecting soil spatial heterogeneity.

Definition.Question: What are the typical methods for resolving the spatial heterogeneity of soil hydraulic properties in datasets?
Definition.Answer: To address spatial heterogeneity, datasets often rely on multiple PTF-derived soil hydraulic parameters which provide users with options to use either a single set or an ensemble of parameters. These datasets are designed to describe spatial variability in both vertical and horizontal directions, offering a benchmark for regional land surface modeling.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial resolution and depth of soil datasets used for land surface modeling in China?
Comparison.Answer: The dataset for soil hydraulic parameters in China is provided at a spatial resolution of 30 x 30 arc seconds, with soil vertical layering up to a depth of 1.38 meters across seven layers. This detailed resolution is designed to reflect the spatial variability in soil characteristics, which is important for regional land surface modeling.

Interpretation.Question: How can the spatial heterogeneity of soil hydraulic properties be effectively captured and represented in a dataset despite the challenges of direct measurement?
Interpretation.Answer: Spatial heterogeneity of soil hydraulic properties can be captured using pedotransfer functions (PTFs) that estimate hydraulic parameters from easily measured soil properties like particle size distribution, bulk density, and soil organic matter content. These methods allow for estimation over large regions without the need for impractical direct measurements, providing a means to reflect soil variability in both vertical and horizontal directions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to employ multiple pedotransfer functions (PTFs) in estimating soil hydraulic parameters?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is necessary to use multiple PTFs because soil hydraulic properties are highly heterogeneous in space, and their estimates are dependent on local soil characteristics. The inability of PTFs to accurately describe complex physical relationships is due to structural errors, limited data for PTF training, and the uncertainty in PTF inputs reflecting soil spatial heterogeneity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainty in the estimation of soil hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainty in estimating soil hydraulic parameters using PTFs arises from the intrinsic inability of PTFs to accurately describe complex physical relationships, limited data used for PTF training, and the uncertainty in PTF inputs to reflect soil spatial heterogeneity at different scales.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of employing multiple pedotransfer functions for estimating soil hydraulic parameters in land surface modeling?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing multiple pedotransfer functions (PTFs) for estimating soil hydraulic parameters can describe the spatial variability of soil hydraulic characteristics in both vertical and horizontal directions, provide multiple choices for users to use either a single set or an ensemble of hydraulic parameters, and offer a benchmark dataset from multiple PTFs. However, the accuracy remains unknown due to the lack of in situ and regional measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the consequences of relying on empirical functions for soil hydraulic parameter estimation without direct measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying on empirical functions without direct measurements can lead to challenges in accurately describing complex physical relationships, as these functions might have structural errors. The intrinsic inability or uncertainty caused by limited data for PTF training and the uncertainty in PTF inputs to reflect soil spatial heterogeneity at different scales can also contribute to estimation inaccuracies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives behind developing a dataset of soil hydraulic parameters using multiple pedotransfer functions in regions of China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to develop a dataset of soil hydraulic parameters associated with two empirical soil functions using multiple pedotransfer functions (PTFs). The dataset aims to describe spatial variability of the soil hydraulic characteristics in both vertical and horizontal directions, provide multiple choices for users to use either a single set or an ensemble of hydraulic parameters associated with different PTFs, and offer a benchmark dataset from multiple PTFs or as a reference dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to explore various empirical relationships between soil hydraulic parameters and soil characteristics in the context of land surface modeling?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because soil hydraulic properties are highly heterogeneous in space, and their estimates depend on local soil characteristics. There is no unique way to relate soil hydraulic properties and soil characteristics, which is why researchers have proposed different empirical relationships, or pedotransfer functions (PTFs), to estimate soil hydraulic parameters. These PTFs are crucial for land surface models as they provide a way to estimate parameters that are difficult or impractical to measure directly.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why would researchers choose to use a dataset with multiple pedotransfer functions for soil hydraulic parameters rather than relying on direct measurements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Researchers might choose to use a dataset with multiple pedotransfer functions because direct measurement of parameters associated with soil hydraulic properties is difficult and often impractical. It is also impossible to obtain sufficient numbers of direct measurements across a region to adequately reflect the spatial heterogeneity of soils. Therefore, using PTFs derived from soil properties that are easily measured and widely available offers a practical alternative to estimate soil hydraulic parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in estimating soil hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions (PTFs) for land surface models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate soil hydraulic parameters using PTFs for land surface models, the process involves selecting frequently used empirical functions, such as those by Clapp and Hornberger (1978) and van Genuchten and Mualem, and applying multiple PTFs to estimate parameters associated with h(u) and K(u) at a 30 x 30 arc second resolution. This process includes using soil properties like particle size distribution, bulk density, and organic matter content to derive hydraulic parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers address the challenges of spatial heterogeneity and measurement limitations when collecting soil hydraulic data at a regional scale?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can address the challenges of spatial heterogeneity and measurement limitations by developing a dataset with multiple PTF-derived soil hydraulic parameters, providing multiple choices for users to either use a single set or an ensemble of parameters. Using a benchmark dataset from multiple PTFs as a reference can help reflect spatial variability in both vertical and horizontal directions, despite the difficulty of direct measurement.

Enablement.Question: What soil characteristics enable the estimation of hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions in land surface modeling?
Enablement.Answer: Soil characteristics such as particle size distribution, bulk density (BD), and soil organic matter (SOM) content enable the estimation of hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions (PTFs) because they are easily measured and widely available.

Enablement.Question: How do multiple pedotransfer functions enable the development of a comprehensive dataset for soil hydraulic parameters?
Enablement.Answer: Multiple pedotransfer functions enable the development of a comprehensive dataset for soil hydraulic parameters by providing multiple choices for users to utilize either a single set or an ensemble of hydraulic parameters, describing the spatial variability of soil hydraulic characteristics in both vertical and horizontal directions, and offering benchmark or reference datasets by aggregating median values from various PTFs.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or data sources are essential to enable the accurate spatial representation of soil hydraulic properties across a region?
Enablement.Answer: To enable the accurate spatial representation of soil hydraulic properties across a region, it is essential to have comprehensive data sources like a detailed soil characteristics dataset and representative soil profiles, as well as methodologies that can address the intrinsic inability or uncertainties of PTFs due to limited training data and spatial heterogeneity of soils.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the challenges involved in using pedotransfer functions (PTFs) for estimating soil hydraulic parameters on a regional scale?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in using PTFs for estimating soil hydraulic parameters on a regional scale include the intrinsic inability of PTFs to accurately describe complex physical relationships, the uncertainty caused by limited data used for PTF training, and the uncertainty in PTF inputs to reflect soil spatial heterogeneity at different scales. Additionally, direct measurement of parameters is difficult and impractical, making it impossible to adequately capture the spatial heterogeneity of soils across a region.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the potential benefits and limitations of utilizing multiple pedotransfer functions to develop a regional dataset of soil hydraulic parameters?
Judgmental.Answer: Utilizing multiple pedotransfer functions to develop a regional dataset of soil hydraulic parameters offers potential benefits such as the ability to describe spatial variability of soil hydraulic characteristics in both vertical and horizontal directions and providing multiple choices for users to use either a single set or an ensemble of hydraulic parameters. However, limitations include the unknown accuracy due to a lack of in situ and regional measurements and the difficulty in quantifying the precision of the hydraulic parameter data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential improvements or future directions for data collection methods in enhancing the accuracy and reliability of soil hydraulic parameter datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvements or future directions for data collection methods could include increasing the number of in situ measurements to better capture spatial heterogeneity, updating the information on the spatial distribution of soils, and employing advanced techniques to improve the precision of hydraulic parameter data. Additionally, integrating new technologies or methodologies to reduce the intrinsic structural errors of PTFs might enhance the datasets' accuracy and reliability.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how soil hydraulic parameters can be accurately estimated using pedotransfer functions given the spatial heterogeneity of soils.
Assertion.Answer: The estimation of soil hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions is based on empirical relationships between easily measured soil properties like particle size distribution, bulk density, and soil organic matter content. This approach is necessary because direct measurement of parameters is difficult and impractical over large regions. However, the accuracy of these estimates can be limited due to the inherent structural errors in pedotransfer functions and the limited data used for their training, which leads to uncertainties in capturing soil spatial heterogeneity.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to develop a dataset that accounts for the vertical and horizontal variability of soil hydraulic characteristics.
Assertion.Answer: The development of a dataset that captures vertical and horizontal variability involves using multiple pedotransfer functions to estimate hydraulic parameters associated with empirical soil functions like water retention curves and hydraulic conductivity. The dataset is generated at a fine resolution of 30 x 30 arc seconds and includes seven vertical soil layers up to a depth of 1.38 meters, providing detailed spatial variability of soil hydraulic characteristics.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how a dataset can be reliable without in situ and regional measurements to validate its accuracy.
Assertion.Answer: While the dataset's accuracy is unknown due to the lack of in situ and regional measurements, it leverages the best available soil characteristics dataset for China, derived from a comprehensive soil map and numerous representative soil profiles. The dataset offers estimated median values and variability indices for hydraulic parameters, serving as a benchmark or reference for users despite the inherent uncertainties from relying on pedotransfer functions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the general methodologies involved in estimating soil hydraulic parameters using pedotransfer functions for regional land surface modeling.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies in estimating soil hydraulic parameters involve the use of pedotransfer functions (PTFs) that rely on empirical relationships between soil characteristics such as particle size distribution, bulk density, and soil organic matter content. These PTFs are applied to calculate parameters for soil water retention curves and hydraulic conductivity functions, specifically using models like those of Clapp and Hornberger, van Genuchten, and Mualem. The parameters are estimated at a high spatial resolution and across multiple vertical soil layers.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the main challenges faced in data collection for soil hydraulic parameter datasets and how these challenges could be addressed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges in data collection include the difficulty of direct measurement of soil hydraulic parameters due to spatial heterogeneity, the impracticality of obtaining sufficient direct measurements across a region, and uncertainties in PTF estimates due to limited data and structural errors. Addressing these challenges requires improving the precision of hydraulic parameter data, updating spatial distributions of soil data, and enhancing PTF reliability with more comprehensive datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential sources or strategies for expanding soil hydraulic parameter datasets to better reflect spatial heterogeneity.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand datasets, researchers can utilize more extensive soil profile data and increase the resolution of soil maps, such as the 1:1,000,000 Soil Map of China. Employing a wider range of PTFs and integrating diverse soil characteristics could also help capture spatial heterogeneity. Collaborative efforts to update regional soil data and incorporate remote sensing technologies could provide additional insights and data accuracy.
